question.title: Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

[image]

user_prompts:
QUESTIONS: {'P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('77b0861e-8cdf-4834-a213-e075e51a0473'), title='Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

(b) Will Elon Musk make a public announcement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES if either of the following occurs: (a) Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024. (b) Elon Musk publicly discusses Bitcoin at any event during the calendar year 2024.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=False), 'Q_and_not_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('006319af-744d-45aa-b261-15ad1bb13242'), title='Will both of the following occur: (a) Elon Musk makes a public announcement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024 and (b) Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES if both of the following conditions are met: (1) Elon Musk publicly discusses Bitcoin at any event during the calendar year 2024, and (2) Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None), 'Q_given_P': ForecastingQuestion(id=UUID('6c60623f-5dad-4226-bfaa-616b8bad47e8'), title='Given Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, will he make a public announcement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024?', body='This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk becomes a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024. Additionally, this market will resolve YES if Elon Musk publicly discusses Bitcoin at any event during the calendar year 2024. Therefore, the question is: Given that Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, will he make a public announcement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024?', resolution_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), question_type='conditional_binary', data_source='synthetic_inst', created_date=datetime.datetime(2024, 7, 23, 12, 19, 25, tzinfo=TzInfo(UTC)), url=None, metadata=None, resolution=None)}

GENERAL: Output your general reasoning and thought process.  Here you can be as detailed as you want, mentioning the reasoning of your predictions and how / why each prediction obeys the given consistency rules.  If there are multiple questions P, Q, you can also make comments on their independence or relationship with each other.

PROB: Output your probability estimates of each of the variables (P, Q, not_P, etc.).  Here, ONLY output the labels, their associated predictions, and NOTHING ELSE. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    P: 0.xx,
    not_P: 0.xx,
    P_or_Q: 0.xx,
    ...

CHECK: Go through each rule in CONSISTENCY RULES and check whether each rule is obeyed with your given predictions.  For each rule, first print the mathematical rule and the associated predicted values associated with it.  Then think VERY carefully about whether the outputs obey the mathematical rule. Then output whether it obeys the rule. At the end, print out a summary on whether all of the rules passed, or which ones failed. Your output MUST look and be formatted as follows.
    neg: P = 1- not_P, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, EQUATION is EVALUATION, 
    and:  max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), EQUATION is EVALUATION,
    ...
    {ALL consistency checks passed!} OR {failed_check_1, failed_check_2 ... consistency checks failed!

PROB: Now again output your probability estimates of each variable in a dict like format like before, but taking account and correcting any consistency violations that occurred.
        Note that changing the predicted probability of one value to satisfy one consistency rule will also affect consistency rules for others.  It is IMPERATIVE that any changes made still ensure all other consistency checks pass too.
        If there were no violations found, then simply output the same dict again.  Your output MUST look like and be formatted as follows.
        P: 0.xx,
        not_P: 0.xx,
        P_or_Q: 0.xx,
        ...
FLOAT: Now just output your probability estimate of P and nothing else as a decimal!

RECEIVED

para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.73 = 1 - 0.27 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.83 + 0.23 - 0.33 is TRUE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73, + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.83 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is TRUE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.83 - 0.10 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.73 ≈ 0.23 / 0.32 is TRUE
para: P = para_P, 0.73 = 0.73 is TRUE
ALL consistency checks passed!

andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.73 = 0.71 + 0.23 - 0.33 is FALSE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.73 + 0.33 - 1, 0) <= 0.23 <= min(0.73, 0.33) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.73, 0.33) <= 0.71 <= min(1, 0.73 + 0.33) is FALSE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.73 = 0.71 - 0.12 is FALSE

P: 0.73
not_P: 0.27
para_P: 0.73
Q: 0.33
P_and_Q: 0.23
P_or_Q: 0.83
Q_and_not_P: 0.10
Q_given_P: 0.32

0.73

RECEIVED

In this scenario, we are evaluating the likelihood of Elon Musk's attendance and announcements related to Bitcoin at the Nashville 2024 conference. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is a straightforward question about attendance. Given Musk's public interest in Bitcoin, I estimate a moderate probability that he will attend, say around 0.60.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is the complement of P. If P is 0.60, then not_P would be 0.40. 

3. **para_P (Is it certain that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is a more stringent condition and I would expect this to have a lower probability than P, perhaps around 0.30, as certainty is difficult to predict.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public announcement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024?)**: Given Musk's active engagement with Bitcoin, I would estimate a probability of around 0.70 for this event.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both occur: (1) Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, and (2) he makes a public announcement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024?)**: This probability would be lower than either P or Q alone, as both events need to happen. A reasonable estimate might be around 0.40.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either of the following occur: (a) Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024? (b) Will he make a public announcement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024?)**: This should be higher than either P or Q alone, so I would estimate this to be around 0.80.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both occur: (a) Elon Musk makes a public announcement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024 and (b) he does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This scenario is plausible, but the probability should be moderate, say around 0.25.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, will he make a public announcement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024?)**: This conditional probability should be higher than Q alone, as his attendance could increase the likelihood of making an announcement. I would estimate this to be around 0.75.

Overall, I believe these estimates should respect the consistency rules, particularly the relationships between the events and their complements.

P: 0.60,
not_P: 0.40,
para_P: 0.30,
Q: 0.70,
P_and_Q: 0.40,
P_or_Q: 0.80,
Q_and_not_P: 0.25,
Q_given_P: 0.75

neg: P = 1 - not_P, 0.60 = 1 - 0.40 is TRUE
andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.60 = 0.80 + 0.40 - 0.70 is FALSE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.60 + 0.70 - 1, 0) <= 0.40 <= min(0.60, 0.70) is FALSE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.60, 0.70) <= 0.80 <= min(1, 0.60 + 0.70) is FALSE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.60 = 0.80 - 0.25 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.60 ≈ 0.40 / 0.75 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.60 = 0.30 is FALSE

andor, and, or, cond, para consistency checks failed!

P: 0.60,
not_P: 0.40,
para_P: 0.30,
Q: 0.70,
P_and_Q: 0.30,
P_or_Q: 0.80,
Q_and_not_P: 0.25,
Q_given_P: 0.75

0.6

question.title: Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?
question.body:
This market will resolve YES, if Elon Musk does not become a guest on the official stage of the Bitcoin Nashville 2024, one of the largest Bitcoin conferences, taking place on July 25-27, 2024.

For the questions regarding Elon Musk's participation in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 event and his public announcements about Bitcoin, I will evaluate the probabilities based on the nature of the events and their interdependencies.

1. **P (Elon Musk shows up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: This event is highly contingent on Elon Musk's schedule and interest in Bitcoin events. Given his past involvement with cryptocurrency, I would estimate a moderate probability for this event occurring, say around 0.60.

2. **not_P (Elon Musk does not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024)**: Since this is the complement of P, it would be 1 - P, which would be 0.40.

3. **para_P (Is it certain that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is essentially asking for certainty. Given that there are many variables at play, I would estimate this as very low, perhaps around 0.10.

4. **Q (Elon Musk makes a public announcement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024)**: Given his active engagement with Bitcoin and cryptocurrency, I would assign a relatively higher probability to this event, estimating it at around 0.70.

5. **P_and_Q (Both P and Q occur)**: The occurrence of both events is less likely than each occurring independently. If I estimate P at 0.60 and Q at 0.70, I might calculate P_and_Q as 0.60 * 0.70 = 0.42, but I should also consider their potential dependence, which might reduce this value slightly.

6. **P_or_Q (Either P or Q occurs)**: This can be calculated using the formula P + Q - P_and_Q. If I take P as 0.60 and Q as 0.70, and estimate P_and_Q as 0.42, then P_or_Q would be 0.60 + 0.70 - 0.42 = 0.88.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Q occurs while P does not)**: This is a specific case where Q happens but P does not. If I assume that Q has a probability of 0.70 and not_P is 0.40, I might estimate this at around 0.28 (0.70 * 0.40), but again, I should consider their dependence.

8. **Q_given_P (Q occurs given P occurs)**: This conditional probability would likely be higher than the standalone Q probability, as if Musk attends the Bitcoin Nashville event, he may be more inclined to make announcements about Bitcoin. I might estimate this at around 0.80.

In summary, I will adjust my probability estimates based on these considerations, ensuring they adhere to the consistency rules. The key relationships to keep in mind are that P and not_P are complements, and P_and_Q is influenced by both P and Q.

P: 0.60,
not_P: 0.40,
para_P: 0.10,
Q: 0.70,
P_and_Q: 0.42,
P_or_Q: 0.88,
Q_and_not_P: 0.28,
Q_given_P: 0.80

andor: P = P_or_Q + P_and_Q - Q, 0.60 = 0.88 + 0.42 - 0.70 is FALSE
and: max(P + Q - 1, 0) <= P_and_Q <= min(P, Q), max(0.60 + 0.70 - 1, 0) <= 0.42 <= min(0.60, 0.70) is TRUE
or: max(P, Q) <= P_or_Q <= min(1, P + Q), max(0.60, 0.70) <= 0.88 <= min(1, 0.60 + 0.70) is FALSE
but: P = P_or_Q - Q_and_not_P, 0.60 = 0.88 - 0.28 is TRUE
cond: P ≈ P_and_Q / Q_given_P, 0.60 ≈ 0.42 / 0.80 is FALSE
para: P = para_P, 0.60 = 0.10 is FALSE

question.title: Will OpenAI publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?

In assessing the probability estimates for the questions regarding Elon Musk's involvement in the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 event and his public announcements about Bitcoin in 2024, I consider several factors.

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: Given Elon Musk's history of engaging with the Bitcoin community, I estimate a moderate probability of him attending the event. Factors include his previous appearances at Bitcoin-related events and the significance of this conference.

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is estimated at 0.73, then not_P would be 0.27.

3. **para_P (Is it certain that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is a stronger assertion than P, so I would expect it to be lower than P. I estimate it at 0.65.

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public announcement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024?)**: Given Elon Musk's active engagement with Bitcoin, I estimate this probability to be relatively high, around 0.70.

5. **P_and_Q (Will both occur: Musk shows up at Nashville and makes an announcement about Bitcoin?)**: This probability should be lower than either P or Q. I estimate it at 0.50, reflecting the joint occurrence.

6. **P_or_Q (Will either occur: Musk shows up at Nashville or makes an announcement about Bitcoin?)**: This probability should be higher than either P or Q but less than 1. I estimate it at 0.80, indicating a strong likelihood that at least one event will occur.

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both occur: Musk makes an announcement and does not show up at Nashville?)**: This is a more specific scenario, so I estimate it to be lower, around 0.20.

8. **Q_given_P (Given Musk shows up at Nashville, will he make an announcement about Bitcoin?)**: This conditional probability should be high since showing up at the event likely increases the chance of making an announcement. I estimate it at 0.85.

In terms of consistency, I will ensure that the estimates adhere to the rules outlined. For instance, since not_P is the complement of P, they should sum to 1. Additionally, the probabilities for P_and_Q and Q_and_not_P must adhere to the logical relationships defined in the consistency rules.

In this scenario, we are evaluating the probabilities of various events related to Elon Musk's involvement with the Bitcoin Nashville 2024 conference and his public announcements about Bitcoin in 2024. 

1. **P (Will Elon Musk show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This event is likely influenced by Musk's previous engagements, public interest in Bitcoin, and the nature of the conference. Given Musk's history with Bitcoin and similar events, I estimate a moderate to high probability of him attending, say around 0.65. 

2. **not_P (Will Elon Musk not show up at the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This is simply the complement of P. If P is 0.65, then not_P would be 0.35. 

3. **para_P (Is it certain that Elon Musk will attend the Bitcoin Nashville 2024?)**: This question is slightly more stringent than P. If I believe there is a 65% chance he will attend, then I might estimate this at around 0.50, reflecting uncertainty. 

4. **Q (Will Elon Musk make a public announcement about Bitcoin at any event in 2024?)**: Given Musk's active presence in the cryptocurrency space, I would estimate a probability of around 0.70 for this event. 

5. **P_and_Q (Will both P and Q occur?)**: This is a conjunction of two events. Assuming P and Q are somewhat independent, I would calculate this as P * Q, which would be 0.65 * 0.70 = 0.455. 

6. **P_or_Q (Will either P or Q occur?)**: This is calculated using the formula P + Q - P_and_Q. So, 0.65 + 0.70 - 0.455 = 0.895. 

7. **Q_and_not_P (Will both Q occur and not P occur?)**: This is more complex. If Q is 0.70 and not_P is 0.35, I would estimate this at around 0.20, considering that both cannot happen if P is true. 

8. **Q_given_P (Given P occurs, will Q occur?)**: This conditional probability could be high, assuming that if Musk shows up, he might also make an announcement. I might estimate this at around 0.80. 

After estimating these probabilities, I will check them against the consistency rules to ensure they align correctly. The relationships between the events are important, as they help to determine the overall probabilities and ensure that they follow the logical constraints laid out by the consistency rules.
